newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Ruling Montenegrin party splits in two.
newsitem.headline: Ruling Montenegrin party splits in two.

text.p: Montenegro's ruling DPS party split in two on Friday when reformers ousted President Momir Bulatovic as party leader.
A third of the DPS main board left with Bulatovic who predicted the holding of early presidential elections to settle his running dispute with Prime Minister Milo Djukanovic.
Djukanovic, an open opponent of Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic, emerged as favourite for the DPS nomination for the presidency.
Elections are due to be held by November.

Former Montenegrin culture minister Goran Rakocevic told Belgrade's Radio Index that the split could lead to Montenegro's rejection of support for Milosevic's expected bid to become president of Federal Yugoslavia.
Djukanovic has accused Milosevic of slowing Montenegro's economic development by refusing cooperation with the international community since the lifting of U.N. sanctions against Yugoslavia.
Montenegro has equal status with Serbia in the federation despite being a fraction of its size in terms of population and its economy.
